pillar_title: Living Under the Label: Stupid, Lazy, or Just ADHD?

spokes.title: Why ADHD Makes You Feel Dumb, Even When You're Not
spokes.description: Explores the deep-seated feelings of inadequacy, low confidence, and self-doubt that arise from ADHD challenges, often leading to harsh self-criticism and identity issues.
manifestations: Self-criticism and fixation on perceived mistakes
Feeling inadequate and low confidence
Struggles with emotional regulation, impulsivity, and social interactions leading to self-doubt
Withdrawing or isolating due to shame
Difficulty saying 'no' due to a desire to please
psychological_underpinnings: Emotional dysregulation and impulsivity
Executive function deficits making it difficult to meet expectations
Rejection sensitivity, leading to perceived inadequacy
Constant comparison to neurotypical peers
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of dopaminergic signaling impacting emotional regulation and reward processing
Differences in prefrontal cortex affecting executive functioning and self-regulation
Atypical functioning in amygdala and prefrontal cortex for emotional regulation

spokes.title: The 'Lazy' Label: When It's Really Just ADHD
spokes.description: Explores how challenges with motivation, organization, and task completion are misinterpreted as laziness, leading to profound guilt, shame, and a negative self-view.
manifestations: Difficulty with motivation for routine tasks
Challenges meeting deadlines, staying organized, finishing tasks
Perceived failure and social challenges (e.g., interrupting)
Self-criticism and negative self-talk
psychological_underpinnings: Executive dysfunction (motivation, organization)
Chronic sense of underachievement despite efforts
Internalized guilt and shame from external criticism
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of dopaminergic signaling impacting motivation and reward pathways
Differences in prefrontal cortex affecting task initiation and sustained effort
Time-blindness affecting ability to estimate and manage task completion

spokes.title: When Others Think You're Stupid: Navigating ADHD and External Judgment
spokes.description: Addresses the intense emotional pain and self-perception issues arising from the belief that others view individuals with ADHD as unintelligent or incompetent, often amplified by rejection sensitivity.
manifestations: Anticipating frustration or disappointment from others
Believing self-statements like 'I am clumsy, stupid, lazy'
Difficulty trusting others due to past judgment
psychological_underpinnings: Rejection Sensitivity Dysphoria (RSD)
Cognitive distortions (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing thinking)
Internalization of years of feeling judged and dismissed
neurobiological_mechanisms: Overreaction of the HPA axis to perceived rejection
Lower dopamine levels impacting emotional balance and increasing sensitivity to negative feedback
Less filtering in the brain's communication center, leading to quicker, heightened emotional reactions

spokes.title: The Invisible Chains: Unpacking ADHD Internalized Ableism
spokes.description: Examines how societal biases and expectations lead individuals with ADHD to internalize negative beliefs about their own neurotype, resulting in self-doubt, shame, and a tendency to hide their struggles.
manifestations: Self-doubt and confusion about capabilities
Believing damaging labels ('lazy,' 'stupid,' 'too much')
Hiding struggles out of shame
Perfectionism and people-pleasing as overcompensation
Resistance to seeking help ('I should figure it out alone')
psychological_underpinnings: Internalization of societal biases and expectations
The 'ADHD Shadow' – a painful internal narrative formed before diagnosis
Mistaking societal expectations for one's own capabilities
neurobiological_mechanisms: Impact of chronic stress (from masking/hiding) on brain function
Potential for neuroplastic changes reinforcing negative self-beliefs
HPA axis dysregulation from continuous perceived threat/judgment

spokes.title: The Echo of Childhood: Unpacking ADHD Labels That Stick
spokes.description: Examines how early negative labels ('lazy,' 'disruptive') influence self-perception, contribute to low self-esteem, and foster an internalized sense of being fundamentally flawed in individuals with ADHD.
manifestations: Being labeled 'lazy,' 'disruptive,' 'underachieving' at school
Being labeled 'forgetful,' 'unmotivated,' 'disorganized' at home
Internalizing negative messages and seeing oneself as flawed
Developing perfectionism or self-criticism as a coping mechanism
psychological_underpinnings: Misunderstanding of ADHD symptoms leading to frequent negative feedback
Learned helplessness from repeated perceived failures
Rejection Sensitivity Dysphoria amplifying impact of criticism
neurobiological_mechanisms: Chronic stress from negative feedback impacting developing brain (HPA axis)
Reinforcement of negative neural pathways related to self-perception
Heightened amygdala activity in response to social threats

spokes.title: The Backpack of Shame: ADHD and the Legacy of School Struggles
spokes.description: Focuses on the lasting impact of shame experienced in academic settings due to ADHD, contributing to internalized failure, avoidance behaviors, and emotional distress.
manifestations: Avoidance of challenging tasks and social interactions
Disruptive behaviors as defense mechanisms
Disengagement from learning
Heightened stress and anxiety in academic settings
psychological_underpinnings: Internalization of failure due to nonconformity and negative feedback
Rejection sensitivity amplifying impact of teacher/peer reactions
Fear of judgment and anticipated negative reactions
neurobiological_mechanisms: Chronic activation of stress response (HPA axis) in school environment
Impact on executive functions (e.g., working memory, inhibition) due to anxiety
Sensory overwhelm in classroom setting leading to dysregulation

spokes.title: Undoing the Damage: Rebuilding Self-Worth with ADHD
spokes.description: Explores the profound impact of ADHD on self-worth, leading to persistent feelings of inadequacy, self-criticism, and a diminished sense of value, often stemming from lifelong struggles and criticism.
manifestations: Self-blame, poor self-esteem, feelings of inadequacy
Self-criticism and perfectionistic tendencies
Difficulty saying 'no' and withdrawing/isolating
Negative self-image and feeling like a fraud
psychological_underpinnings: Frequent criticism and invalidating environments
Challenges with memory, organization, concentration, time-blindness
Interpersonal struggles and emotional dysregulation
Rejection sensitivity
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of the brain's reward system (dopamine) impacting sense of accomplishment
Chronic stress and HPA axis dysregulation impacting mood and self-perception
Neuroplastic changes reinforcing negative self-beliefs over time

spokes.title: The 'Always in Trouble' Trap: How ADHD Leads to Constant Criticism
spokes.description: Investigates how ADHD symptoms lead to frequent negative feedback and consequences, fostering a deep sense of embarrassment, unworthiness, and a belief in inherent flaw despite intentions.
manifestations: Repeated failures or difficulties in various aspects of life
Social withdrawal and procrastination
Decreased motivation and relationship strain
Avoidance behaviors to cope with anticipated negative outcomes
psychological_underpinnings: ADHD symptoms leading to actions that break social expectations (e.g., interrupting)
Frequent criticism and internalizing struggles as personal failures
Emotional dysregulation and rejection sensitivity
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysfunction in impulse control and emotional regulation pathways
Lower dopamine activity affecting reward processing and motivation, leading to risk-taking or withdrawal
Chronic stress response (HPA axis) due to repeated negative experiences

spokes.title: The 'Never Good Enough' Syndrome: ADHD and the Pursuit of Perfection
spokes.description: Delves into the relentless feeling of inadequacy despite accomplishments, often driven by imposter syndrome, perfectionism, and a deep-seated belief of fundamental deficiency.
manifestations: Working twice as hard, making more mistakes
Hiding struggles and imposter syndrome
Constant self-doubt and endlessly working on overdrive
Rejecting praise and depending on others for validation
psychological_underpinnings: Belief that successes are due to external factors (luck)
Fear of being 'found out as a fraud'
Underlying guilt and shame, core belief of deficiency
Sensitivity to criticism (RSD) and all-or-nothing thinking
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulated reward pathways (dopamine) making internal validation difficult
Differences in cognitive flexibility impacting ability to adjust self-perception
Chronic stress and anxiety impacting self-worth neural circuits

spokes.title: Breaking the Mold: Escaping an ADHD Failure Identity
spokes.description: Explores how repeated experiences of failure and external criticism can lead to a deeply ingrained sense of self as a 'failure,' fostering shame, self-hatred, and a disconnect from one's authentic self.
manifestations: Deeply ingrained shame and self-hatred
Belief that something is fundamentally wrong with them
Feeling alienated/disconnected from true selves
Resistance to self-compassion/self-acceptance
psychological_underpinnings: Repeated experiences of failure/criticism
External judgment morphing into internalized shame
Constant struggle to meet external expectations ('I am broken' belief)
neurobiological_mechanisms: Chronic stress responses leading to amygdala sensitization and heightened emotional reactivity
Impaired self-perception due to altered neural pathways related to self-referential processing
Dysfunction in reward pathways hindering development of positive self-reinforcement

spokes.title: Teacher Trauma: Healing from Educational Wounds with ADHD
spokes.description: Explores how negative experiences with teachers, often due to misunderstanding ADHD symptoms, can lead to a sense of shame, self-loathing, defectiveness, and hypervigilance in individuals with ADHD.
manifestations: Difficulty concentrating, poor memory, emotional dysregulation (overlapping with ADHD symptoms)
Hypervigilance and frantic learning systems to prevent criticism
Anxiety/adrenaline for task focus
Being labeled 'dramatic' or 'overly-sensitive'
psychological_underpinnings: Higher frequency of traumatic experiences in ADHDers
Caregivers/teachers misunderstanding ADHD differences
Deep sense of shame, self-loathing, and defectiveness
neurobiological_mechanisms: Chronic activation of the HPA axis due to ongoing stress/criticism
Impact on developing brain regions responsible for emotional regulation and executive functions
Heightened amygdala response to perceived threats, leading to hypervigilance

spokes.title: The Unspoken Burden: Living with ADHD's Silent Struggles
spokes.description: Addresses the hidden challenges and internal battles faced by individuals with ADHD, often manifesting as shyness, social anxiety, and avoidance due to past negative experiences and fear of judgment.
manifestations: Shyness, social anxiety, avoiding drawing attention
Keeping quiet, difficulty with social cues, struggling to find words
Masking symptoms and avoiding social interactions to protect self-esteem
psychological_underpinnings: Past experiences of misunderstanding and negative social interactions
Constant struggle to focus/attend, leading to embarrassment
Self-consciousness and fear of making mistakes/judgment
neurobiological_mechanisms: Overactive fear response pathways (amygdala) in social situations
Impaired social cognition due to executive dysfunction (e.g., working memory for social cues)
Dopamine dysregulation impacting social motivation and reward

spokes.title: Beyond 'Disruptive': Understanding the ADHD Experience Behind the Label
spokes.description: Explores how individuals, particularly women with ADHD, are often mislabeled as disruptive or inadequate due to internalized symptoms and emotional sensitivity, leading to self-blame and low self-esteem.
manifestations: Internalized sense of impairment, hiding differences
Reluctance to ask for help, second-guessing oneself
Anticipating criticism/rejection, censoring self
Frustration leading to outbursts at home
Rigid perfectionism and self-monitoring
psychological_underpinnings: Restrictive gender roles and societal expectations (for women)
Chronic underlying feelings of inadequacy and shame
Masking and imposter syndrome
Emotional reactivity and perceived failures in self-regulation
neurobiological_mechanisms: Gender differences in ADHD presentation impacting diagnosis and support
Atypical functioning in emotional regulation circuits contributing to 'outbursts'
Impact of chronic stress from masking on executive functions

spokes.title: The Shadow of Scrutiny: ADHD and the Fear of Judgment
spokes.description: Explores how ADHD amplifies the fear of being judged or criticized, often due to Rejection Sensitivity Dysphoria, leading to social withdrawal, people-pleasing, and rumination.
manifestations: Social withdrawal and overthinking interactions
Persistent fear of failure and people-pleasing
Suppressing needs/boundaries to gain acceptance
Rejecting others first (outbursts, anger, defiance)
Ruminating over perceived slights
psychological_underpinnings: Rejection Sensitivity Dysphoria (RSD)
Heightened emotional sensitivity and social conditioning (frequent reprimands)
Low self-esteem and emotional dysregulation
neurobiological_mechanisms: Neurological differences affecting emotional regulation and impulse control
Lower dopamine levels impacting emotional balance and increasing sensitivity to rejection
Overactive amygdala response to perceived social threats

spokes.title: The Fear of Fumbling: ADHD and the Anxiety of Appearing Unintelligent
spokes.description: Explores how toxic shame and an ingrained belief of inadequacy drive a pervasive fear of appearing unintelligent or uninformed, leading to self-sabotage and avoidance of essential questions.
manifestations: Avoiding asking questions ('I should know this')
Thinking 'everyone else knows,' 'I should figure this out'
Constant hiding and second-guessing
Difficulty processing information (reading/re-reading)
psychological_underpinnings: Toxic shame response
Underlying assumption that everyone else knows something you don't
Fear of revealing lack of knowledge due to past negative experiences ('Are you stupid?')
neurobiological_mechanisms: Heightened activity in brain regions associated with social anxiety and fear
Dysfunction in executive functions impacting ability to seek clarification
Chronic stress impacting working memory and information processing

spokes.title: The Echo Chamber: Living with Constant Self-Doubt and ADHD
spokes.description: Examines the pervasive self-doubt that plagues individuals with ADHD, stemming from low confidence, internalized criticism, and the imposter phenomenon, leading to hesitation and avoidance.
manifestations: Questioning capabilities and hesitation to contribute ideas
Difficulty trusting oneself and overthinking
Anticipating failure and inability to accept praise
Feeling like a fraud and comparing oneself to others
psychological_underpinnings: Low confidence and low self-esteem
Internalized criticism and rejection sensitivity
Imposter syndrome and negative self-talk
Chronic underachievement reinforcing self-doubt
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulated dopamine affecting self-reward and internal validation
Altered prefrontal cortex function impacting decision-making and self-monitoring
Heightened stress response (HPA axis) due to chronic anxiety

spokes.title: The ADHD Overdrive: Always Working to Prove Your Worth
spokes.description: Examines the compulsive drive to overperform and overcompensate due to ADHD, driven by fear of judgment and imposter syndrome, ultimately leading to exhaustion and deeper feelings of inadequacy.
manifestations: Overperforming, overachieving, overcompensating
Setting very high standards and perfectionism
Presenting a seamless façade and relentless self-monitoring
Staying up late for preparations
psychological_underpinnings: Frequent criticism and breaking social expectations
Stigmatization of ADHD and low self-compassion
Fear of judgment and imposter syndrome
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulated reward pathways leading to external validation seeking
Chronic activation of stress response due to constant pressure
Impaired self-regulation (executive functions) driving overcompensation

spokes.title: Hiding in Plain Sight: The ADHD Fear of Being Seen
spokes.description: Addresses the deep-seated fear of revealing one's authentic self due to ADHD, driven by internalized ableism, societal expectations, and the emotional cost of masking.
manifestations: Hyperawareness of how viewed by others
Masking symptoms and emotional exhaustion
Suppression of unique traits/interests and identity loss
Anxiety/panic attacks and avoiding social situations
psychological_underpinnings: Societal expectations to conform to neurotypical norms
Internalized ableism and fear of judgment/confrontation
Worry about appearing unreliable/deficient/wrong
neurobiological_mechanisms: Chronic activation of stress pathways due to constant masking
Impact on self-representation and social cognition networks
Dopamine dysregulation affecting social reward and motivation

spokes.title: From 'Bad Kid' to ADHD: Reclaiming Your Narrative
spokes.description: Addresses the impact of being labeled as a 'bad kid' due to ADHD symptoms, leading to internalized flaws, low self-esteem, self-blame, and emotional shutdowns.
manifestations: Being seen as disobedient, problematic, difficult
Impulsive behaviors leading to negative consequences
Internalizing negative labels and feeling inherently flawed
Low self-esteem, self-blame, anxiety, social isolation
psychological_underpinnings: Misunderstanding of ADHD symptoms (impulsivity, emotional dysregulation)
Frequent negative feedback and criticism
Rejection Sensitivity Dysphoria (RSD)
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of impulse control and emotional regulation systems
Impact of early negative experiences on developing self-concept neural networks
Chronic stress and HPA axis activation leading to emotional shutdowns

spokes.title: The Reality Gap: ADHD and the Struggle Between Expectation and Performance
spokes.description: Examines the internal and external conflicts arising from the mismatch between personal and societal expectations and the reality of ADHD symptoms, leading to masking, imposter syndrome, and self-doubt.
manifestations: Overpromising and doing extra work
Magnifying challenges and dismissing victories
Overcompensating and perfectionism
Intolerance for others' tardiness (due to own past struggles)
psychological_underpinnings: Masking ADHD symptoms
Feelings of inadequacy and low self-worth
Imposter syndrome and unrealistic expectations
Sensitivity to perceived faults
neurobiological_mechanisms: Executive dysfunction impacting planning and task execution
Dysregulated reward pathways leading to external validation seeking
Chronic anxiety and stress impacting cognitive function

spokes.title: RSD: The Secret Pain Behind ADHD's Fear of Judgment
spokes.description: A foundational concept explaining extreme emotional pain from perceived rejection, criticism, or failure, underpinning many of the shame-related experiences in ADHD.
manifestations: Intense emotional pain to perceived rejection/criticism
Anticipating frustration/disappointment even when not present
Catastrophizing negative social interactions
Emotional outbursts or withdrawal as coping mechanisms
psychological_underpinnings: Heightened emotional sensitivity
Social conditioning from frequent reprimands
Low self-esteem
Childhood emotional invalidation and shaming
neurobiological_mechanisms: Overreaction of the HPA axis (stress response system)
Lower dopamine levels impacting emotional balance and increasing sensitivity to rejection
Impaired executive functioning making it difficult to pause and re-evaluate reactions
Overactive amygdala response to social threats

spokes.title: The Imposter Within: ADHD and the Fear of Being 'Found Out'
spokes.description: Examines how individuals with ADHD often feel like frauds despite accomplishments, driven by core beliefs of inadequacy, fear of exposure, and a tendency to attribute success to luck rather than effort.
manifestations: Feeling like a 'fraud' despite accomplishments
Attributing success to external factors (luck)
Fear of being 'found out' as incompetent
Difficulty accepting praise and rejecting compliments
psychological_underpinnings: Underlying guilt and shame
Core belief of deficiency
Perfectionism and overcompensation
Sensitivity to criticism (RSD)
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulated reward pathways (dopamine) making internal validation difficult
Differences in cognitive flexibility impacting self-perception adjustment
Chronic stress and anxiety impacting self-worth neural circuits

spokes.title: The Master of Disguise: ADHD Masking and its Hidden Costs
spokes.description: Explores the psychological and emotional toll of suppressing ADHD symptoms to appear neurotypical, driven by imposter syndrome and perfectionism, leading to identity loss, burnout, and increased anxiety.
manifestations: Hiding ADHD symptoms to blend in
Emotional exhaustion from maintaining a facade
Suppression of unique traits and identity loss
Unrealistic expectations and self-monitoring
Exacerbated anxiety and self-criticism
psychological_underpinnings: Internalized ableism and societal pressure to conform
Fear of judgment, confrontation, or appearing deficient
Imposter syndrome and perfectionism driving the need to hide
Lack of authenticity and disconnection from true self
neurobiological_mechanisms: Chronic activation of the stress response due to constant effort
Impact on self-representation networks in the brain
Depletion of cognitive resources from continuous self-regulation

spokes.title: The Paradox of Perfection: ADHD and the Pursuit of Flawlessness
spokes.description: Explores how ADHD individuals often strive for unattainable perfection, driven by fear of failure and intense sensitivity to criticism, exacerbating feelings of 'never good enough' and negative self-talk.
manifestations: Setting unrealistic or impossible standards
Excessive self-criticism for minor mistakes
Constant comparison to neurotypical peers
Procrastination due to fear of failure
Intensified Rejection Sensitivity Dysphoria
psychological_underpinnings: Fear of failure and discomfort
Sensitivity to criticism (RSD)
All-or-nothing thinking ('if not perfect, it's a complete failure')
Overcompensation for perceived past errors
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulated reward system leading to seeking flawless outcomes for validation
Impact on executive functions (e.g., inhibition, planning) causing procrastination loop
Chronic anxiety affecting cognitive flexibility and self-correction

spokes.title: Caught in the Loop: Breaking the ADHD Shame Spiral
spokes.description: Explores the vicious cycle where emotional dysregulation, rejection sensitivity, and ADHD traits lead to overwhelming shame, social withdrawal, depression, and self-criticism, reinforcing negative beliefs.
manifestations: Negative self-talk, self-loathing, avoidance behaviors
Intense feelings of anxiety, anger, and frustration escalating into shame
Social withdrawal, depression, and suicidal thoughts
Higher volume of negative messages received by age 10
psychological_underpinnings: Emotional dysregulation
Rejection sensitivity (RSD)
Impulsive behaviors leading to mistakes and guilt
Inattention leading to missed deadlines and self-criticism
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation in amygdala and prefrontal cortex contributing to emotional outbursts
Lower dopamine levels exacerbating sensitivity to rejection and perceived failures
Chronic stress and HPA axis dysregulation impacting mood and self-perception

spokes.title: The Weight of Worthlessness: Overcoming ADHD Toxic Shame
spokes.description: Examines the profound, internalized belief of being fundamentally flawed and unworthy, often stemming from repeated negative experiences and societal judgment, leading to self-hatred and self-destructive tendencies.
manifestations: Deeply ingrained shame and self-hatred
Belief of being inherently flawed or unworthy
Inability to accept affection or trust others' positive regard
Self-destructive tendencies (e.g., self-harm, substance abuse)
Distorted self-perception ('either great or the worst')
psychological_underpinnings: Repeated failures and external criticism leading to internalized shame
Demand avoidance contributing to feelings of overwhelm and failure
Neurobiological basis (low dopamine) contributing to seeking intense sensory input or self-medication
Societal judgment and negative labels ('lazy,' 'not trying hard enough')
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulated dopamine in reward pathways, making intrinsic motivation and self-worth difficult
Impact on prefrontal cortex and amygdala activity, leading to distorted self-perception and emotional intensity
Chronic HPA axis activation due to ongoing internal conflict and external criticism

spokes.title: Self-Sabotage Cycles: Understanding ADHD's Destructive Patterns
spokes.description: Explores how poor impulse control, demand avoidance, and toxic shame can manifest in self-destructive behaviors, further eroding self-esteem and perpetuating negative cycles.
manifestations: Impulsive self-harm (e.g., running into walls, self-injury)
Eating disorders and suicidal ideation
Procrastination and demand avoidance leading to overwhelm
Inability to accept positive regard from others
psychological_underpinnings: Poor impulse control
Demand avoidance (can create feelings of failure)
Toxic shame (belief of being inherently flawed/unworthy)
Seeking intense sensory input or self-medication for low dopamine
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of the prefrontal cortex affecting impulse control and consequence assessment
Lower dopamine levels contributing to sensation-seeking or emotional dysregulation
Impact of chronic stress and shame on neural circuits related to self-worth and self-preservation

spokes.title: The Brain's Architect: How Executive Dysfunction Shapes ADHD Shame
spokes.description: A fundamental aspect of ADHD, describing difficulties with planning, time management, organization, and other cognitive processes that contribute to perceived failures, stress, and low self-esteem.
manifestations: Difficulty with organization, time management, planning
Challenges with task initiation and completion
Inconsistent performance and academic/career struggles
Procrastination and missed deadlines
psychological_underpinnings: Feelings of frustration, inadequacy, and stress
Internalized criticism and self-blame
Lower self-esteem due to chronic struggles
Anxiety and depression from perceived failures
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of dopamine and norepinephrine in prefrontal cortex
Impaired connectivity within executive function networks (e.g., fronto-parietal, cingulo-opercular networks)
Structural and functional differences in brain regions like the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex

spokes.title: The Emotional Rollercoaster: How ADHD Fuels Intense Feelings and Shame
spokes.description: A core ADHD characteristic describing difficulties in managing and expressing emotions, leading to intense feelings, low frustration tolerance, and a predisposition to shame and guilt spirals.
manifestations: Intense feelings of anxiety, anger, and frustration
Low frustration tolerance, feeling overwhelmed/defeated by minor challenges
Impulsively blurting out hurtful comments, overreacting
Difficulty calming down or moving on after stressful events
psychological_underpinnings: Difficulty coping with stress and overreacting to situations
Perceived failures in self-regulation
Triggers like sensory overload, negative feedback, transitions
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of the amygdala and prefrontal cortex
Impaired connectivity between emotional processing and regulatory brain regions
Atypical dopamine signaling impacting emotional stability
Physiological symptoms (rapid heart rate, muscle tension) amplifying emotional state

spokes.title: Impulse Control: The ADHD Brain's Fast Lane and Its Consequences
spokes.description: A core ADHD symptom characterized by acting on urges without forethought, leading to social errors, regretted actions, and contributing to feelings of guilt, shame, and being 'always in trouble'.
manifestations: Frequent interrupting or asking intrusive questions
Accidentally saying things intended to keep to oneself
Acting without pausing to re-evaluate reactions
Blurting out hurtful comments or overreacting
psychological_underpinnings: Difficulty reading nonverbal cues leading to social misunderstandings
Lack of emotional regulation tools
Vicious cycle of shame and guilt from impulsive errors
neurobiological_mechanisms: Dysregulation of dopamine and norepinephrine in frontal-striatal circuits
Underactive prefrontal cortex involvement in behavioral inhibition
Less efficient reward pathways leading to sensation-seeking behavior
